sections.title: Introduction to Motor Control
sections.content:
Basic motor control is the foundation of FTC robot programming. Understanding how to control motor power, direction, and behavior is essential for creating functional robot mechanisms and drivetrains.

For more, see gm0: DC Motors and FTC Docs: Motor Modes.

sections.title: Motor Control Fundamentals
sections.subtitle: Key concepts for motor control:
items: Power ranges from -1.0 (full reverse) to 1.0 (full forward)
Direction can be set globally or controlled with negative power
Zero power behavior determines how motors stop
Run modes control how the motor responds to commands
Safety features prevent damage to motors and mechanisms

sections.title: Power Control
sections.content: The most basic form of motor control is setting power levels. Power determines both speed and direction of the motor. See REV Robotics: Motor Control.

sections.title: Basic Power Control Examples
Direction Control
sections.content: Motor direction can be controlled in two ways: setting the motor direction globally or using negative power values. For drivetrain best practices, see gm0: Drivetrains.

sections.title: Direction Control Methods
Zero Power Behavior
sections.content: Zero power behavior determines what happens when you set motor power to zero. This is important for robot control and safety. See FTC Docs: Motor Modes.

sections.title: Zero Power Behaviors
items: BRAKE: Motor actively resists movement (stops quickly)
FLOAT: Motor coasts to stop (no resistance)
Default: Usually BRAKE for most applications

sections.title: Zero Power Behavior Examples
Run Modes
sections.content: Run modes control how the motor responds to power commands and whether it uses encoder feedback. See FTC Docs: Motor Modes.

sections.title: Common Run Modes
items: RUN_WITHOUT_ENCODER: Direct power control, no encoder feedback
RUN_USING_ENCODER: Power control with encoder-based speed regulation
RUN_TO_POSITION: Move to a specific encoder position
STOP_AND_RESET_ENCODER: Reset encoder to zero position

sections.title: Run Mode Examples
Drivetrain Control
sections.content: Drivetrain control is one of the most common applications of motor control in FTC. Different control schemes offer various advantages. See gm0: Drivetrains.

sections.title: Drivetrain Control Schemes
Safety and Best Practices
sections.content: Implementing safety features and following best practices ensures reliable robot operation and prevents damage. See REV Robotics: Motor Safety.

sections.title: Safety Guidelines
sections.subtitle: Essential safety practices:
items: Always limit power to valid range (-1.0 to 1.0)
Implement emergency stop functionality
Monitor battery voltage and reduce power when low
Test motors at low power before full power
Use appropriate zero power behavior for each application
Check for mechanical binding before running motors

sections.title: Safety Implementation
Troubleshooting
sections.content: Common motor control issues and their solutions help teams quickly resolve problems. See gm0: DC Motors Troubleshooting.

sections.title: Common Issues
items: Motor runs in wrong direction: Change setDirection() or use negative power
Uneven motor speeds: Calibrate power levels or check mechanical issues
Motor doesn't respond: Check configuration file and wiring
Jerky movement: Add smoothing to gamepad inputs
Battery drain: Reduce power levels and check for binding
